content.title: Early Graft Thrombosis
content.definition: Occlusion of a vascular bypass graft within the first 30 days after surgery, typically caused by technical issues or inadequate inflow/outflow.

concepts.definition: Etiologies of thrombosis in the early period.

clinical_features.technical: Anastomotic stenosis, kinking, twisting of graft
clinical_features.conduit: Vein graft issues - retained valve, small caliber

concepts.definition: Signs and symptoms of acute graft thrombosis.

clinical_features.pulses: Loss of previously palpable graft pulse
clinical_features.comparison: Symptoms may be worse than pre-operative if collaterals compromised

clinical_features.duplex: Confirm occlusion, assess inflow and outflow

clinical_features.new_bypass: May require new bypass if graft unsalvageable

content.statement: Early Graft Thrombosis is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Complications that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Early Graft Thrombosis helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Early Graft Thrombosis include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Early Graft Thrombosis.

learning_objectives: Identify technical causes of early failure
Understand the role of completion imaging in prevention
clinical_pearls: Early (<30 days) thrombosis is usually TECHNICAL - look for the cause and fix it
Symptoms may be WORSE than pre-op due to loss of collaterals
Time is critical - delays worsen limb salvage outcomes
Completion imaging detects 5-15% of correctable technical errors
If graft cannot be salvaged, may need new bypass with alternative conduit or route
Always check for hypercoagulable state in unexplained early failure
